186039601.review:
If you may intend to play the game at some time, dont. 

People here are over 50, braindead, toxic as heck and generally do not know what they are doing without having any awareness of the map and their surroundings.,

Balancing is awful in two ways: Matchmaking and damage,

matchmaking: Teams are normally made out of multiple of the four mech classes: Light, Medium, Heavy and Assault. Going in a circle who counters who. This isnt the case anymore, its randomized and often you see yourself as assault against 5-7 lights while having none on your side and vise versa. Dooming your match before it even started.

Damage: Everything is oneshot, your skill points are rated via damage and damage alone. It doesnt matter if your mark your enemies with NARCs for easy missile locks, use a TAG or make good use of your ECM or AMS. It gives no points. It doesnt matter if your destryoed 11k missiles, thats not a single point in your bank. 

Everythin is supposed to do in one shot now and mechs themselves are carrying next to no armor. 

Now, cheating and trolling. The community is pretty open about this, as cheating is easily obersavable in one of every 3 games. be it wallhacks, phx ignore, infinite missile locks etc. And ofc trolls that join and never move after that, or straight up run in and die without doing anything. Theres whole clans that dedicated themselves to this. 

so, do not play this game. Not anymore. It aint worth it.

Now if you want a more intense combined arms experience with respawning and don't mind the lack of a mechlab to change mech loadouts check out Mechwarrior living legends, when that community is active it's also a ton of fun. I got into it recently thanks to a review on this exact game actually and I highly recommend it.

185643200.review: One of the best FPS games out there. Great meta game in regards to fitting your mech with weapons and components. Can tailor the gameplay to your liking. If you like doom/quake, play a light mech, if you want a more war thunder like experience, play assault or heavy.

185551426.review:
Really well balanced excellent multiplayer game with a few minor quirks.

The game is very dependent on player skill, you can make significantly more money by playing well each match. This is largely but not purely based on damage dealt, but generally being roductive attacking the enemy is by far the best moneymaker. Assisting lance and team consistently can also add up to quite a few more match score, which means more c-bills and more XP for your mech variant.

The game has hundreds of mechs to try out each of which functions somewhat like a character class and each having an optimal loadout but many variants have enough flexibility to have numerous loadouts. It can be very overwhelming to start out as a new player when trying to buy your first mech, it's a good idea to seek out opinions of others as at least a starting point.

One of the game's unfortunate quirks is that it runs on a very old version of Cryengine (which is not very multicore optimized), meaning almost inescapable framerate drops on certain maps and in certain areas, at least briefly. 

A second quirk is that it doesn't handle bluetooth headsets particularly well. I recommend having one device to use as a microphone and a second device to use as a headphone (ie disable the mic on your BT headset if you are going to use it).

Oh, and the UI can't be scaled, text will likely be hard for you to read on a 4K display. Recommend playing at lower resolution as a workound if it's unbearable for you.

overall MWO is an excellent choice for online multiplayer FPS, let alone free to play online multiplayer FPS.

The game's further development is funded purely based on its in-game store sales (afaik), so I'm not afraid to spend a little bit here and there even though I don't need it to enjoy the game (at all). They are also fairly generous with events and rewards, and it is also somewhat skill-based.

185518383.review: a great game that retains a lot of battletech qualities. can be played like call of duty or armored core, but not successfully. its definitely its own game.

185477285.review:
Mechwarrior Online was the beginning of the Pig's rampage of mediocrity with the Mechwarrior IP. Now rebranded as "Legends" - because the Pig, in all its spite and avarice, seeks to suppress the truth: there is a better online PvP robo-stompy game.

Mechwarrior: Living Legends is a free combined-arms game built on Crysis Wars, set in the Battletech universe - with playable Tanks, Hovercraft, Power-Armour infantry, VTOLs and Aerospace Fighters in addition to mechs. 

Its main mode is Terrain Control - similar to Domination but on much larger and more varied maps, with respawns, and a per-round economy system - as well as Assault, a semi-linear attack/defend mode. If you've ever played Squad, Project Reality or Battlefield - it's that, but Battletech.

 There are also single-life events and organised games of TC, hosted by the community; a practice server so you can try everything out with other players, and Solaris Arena which is FFA deathmatch.

It has 46 Mech chassis, 20 vehicle chassis, 4 VTOL and 8 ASF - each with 6-8 different variants - ranging from Lights to Assaults; Brawlers, stealth bastards and rangelets, and everything in between. 

No mechlab - and if you've ever got sick of seeing laser boat after lurm boat after gauss boat in MWO - you will, perhaps begrudgingly, understand this is for the best. If there's a specific role you want to play, there are multiple assets that can do it for you.

There's no grind, there's no rank system, and there are no microtransactions - all mech (and other vehicle) skins are free, and you just earn C-bills throughout the round to buy heavier assets later in the round.

Use your favourite search engine, hope to see you there.

185247007.review:
They consistently work towards making the game competitive multiplayer experience by [b]adding levels[/b] that are absolutely [b]not fun[/b]. Instead of reworking the actual problems the game has. For example:

* Unable to chose mech/loadout [i]after[/i] the map has been voted on in quickplay.
* No way to blacklist levels.

That causes me to leave the game when the level [i]'Luthien'[/i] is being voted in. I can accept unoptimized levels like the purple rock one, or the River City. I can deal with open wide area lava levels. Fine. But the [i]'Luthien'[/i] map in particular is just ***. I am a leveldesigner and I could explain to you why.

Polar Highlands (PH), is without a doubt the best map in the game currently. Ishiyama Caves being a close second. Followed by Caustic Valley (CV).
PH and CV both achieve dynamic gameplay without forcing the player into a certain lane. Like [i]Luthien[/i] does. Playing that map feels like being on a rail road with a one way ticket to the bottom of a canyon. If you reach the top it just plateaus into a flat with wide open angles and choke points. The map plays very slow and campy.
Make more terrain maps like CV and PH - they are very good. It allows people to actually maneuver.

185158267.review: This game is aweful.  They constantly release new mechs that have more power and armor and quirks over existing mechs.  These mechs are behind a cash paywall.  When these "new" mechs are later made available to ingame currency(maybe six months) they are often "rebalanced" , limiting their previous overpoweredness. This forces people to constantly need to buy the most recent realeased overpowered mech and prevents free to play players from gaining an advantage.  If you dont care about throwing money at this game you can get an overpowered mech every quarter and can dominate gameplay. if you want to free play you should understand that you will often be obliterated by overpowered mechs. Each mech you play has 91 skill points you need to grind out to optomize the build. This makes you time invested in your substantially inferior mech and you will keep hoping that at some point it can compete.  This is not a good game.

184288925.review:
My favorite part is making builds for the Mechs I have afforded to try out so far. I have always been a free to play player which was pretty tough in the beginning. But since then Mechwarrior Onlines features for new players to play with has drastically improved. More events where you can get the credits and mech bays you need to try new things, and much better Trial Mechs to use. They are actauly giving you viable mechs to start with and you get extra credits when you use them.

The gameplay is really fun. It is so fun to learn the quirks of every weapon and mech, the possibilities are endless. Queue times are almost never longer than a minute. The community is really helpful, especially all the youtubers out there, shoutout to Baradul, TTB and JGx D A T A.

Overall it's always a blast to queue some match's with some friends or alone and blow up some mechs.

183703099.review: Fun immersive game, for those who like the Battle-Tech Universe.

183647620.review:
This is one of the games I've played the most of this year and for good reason. This game feels so much better than War Robots. The mechs and weapons have actual weight to them and you can grind every material super easily! I have very few wishes for this game like more weapons and having the event rewards being redeemable in the game itself but those can hardly be helped with how old this game is. Even then considering how many new mechs are added on a regular basis and it's hard to compete! 

Going back to the War Robot comparisons for a sec; one thing that I always wanted to do in that game is modify the Robots how I want. Enabling me to fix the robot's shortcomings at my discretion. I'll be honest and say that I haven't played War Robots in a few years but that was something I couldn't fix. Shortly after that it also became impossible to A: Keep up (without spending money) and B: Impossible to play on my devices. Like I've said earlier the resources are extremely easy to grind for and the games graphics have antiqued to a degree. It by no means looks like a AAA Game but this game doesn't really need to. It's charming and it's fun to smash my toys against someone else's and seeing whose come out on top.

While I will forever miss my Fujin and Stalker I will forever love my Atlas, Piranha, Catapult, Rifleman, Marauder, Vindicator and more!

183622818.review: Just a constant disappointment. You can call it skill issue, I don't really care. But, even when I play a role the way it's meant to be played, like a LRM boat sitting at the back and sniping, or a Light Mech Scout, or an Assault Brawler, I'll watch my team just panic like headless chickens 9 out of 10 matches, and die to really stupid things, and eventually, just have the enemy team overwhelm me. Or I'll have a light mech just hug my legs, call it out to my team, and it gets to sit there and devour my armor and components with no consequences, because I can't look far enough down, or it's target cloaked. It's trash design, and I while I go back and forth, because I love Battletech, I really just have a hard time liking this game at all. It invalidates and ruins all the things I liked when I got into Mechwarrior in the first place.

183548476.review:
I've been playing since 2014, I'm not a BattleTech fan but the game has me completely hooked
In short, it's a great game.
MWO in the beginning requires quite a lot of time to understand it, but when you pass this stage begins the most interesting. Your skill is the most important thing here, donations will not help.
MWO is quite a complex game and each match is like a mini puzzle, what position to take, choose the right angle depending on your weapon (in what part of the enemy body to shoot) what weapon the opponent has and how to use your weapon competently and so on.

Best community

In short, the whole not usual multiplayer game, in which you need not only to run fast and shoot accurately but also to think, I recommend it to everyone.
even if you are not a Battletech fan.

183530473.review: If you don't mind repetition this game is really great. It ends up feeling more repetitive than a lot of other team shoot-em'-up type games, yet somehow, it's still enjoyable. The biggest downside is the feeling you have early on that the game is pay-to-win, but it is still possible to grind your way into some more competitive equipment. However, you likely won't be playing at top level without padding your skills with some dollars.
